Award.AwardTitle: The Interannual Variability of the Brazil Current
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Brazil Current system is important because: (i) at the surface, it carries warm Tropical Water and has strong eddy variability, forcing in large extent regional weather patterns; (ii) it has a unique vertical structure receiving contributions from several water masses at different levels and latitudes; (iii) it is a western boundary current that closes the South Atlantic subtropical gyre; and (iv) its relative weak time-mean flow indicates strong interactions with the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation. Few investigations exist of the Brazil Current interannual variability, in part because of a lack of in-situ observational data. This study aims at improving the understanding of the Brazil Current system using analysis of a large collection of direct measurements of the Brazil Current and numerical model experiments. The project includes support for an early career principal investigator, mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher, international collaborations with Brazilian universities, and training of college students.

This study investigates the variability of the Brazil Current on interannual timescales, and its relationship to the large-scale mechanisms that drive it. It involves analyzing hydrographic, satellite, and ocean reanalysis data, and performing eddy-resolving modeling experiments. The hydrographic data analysis, which will include a large number of high-density transects, will examine the structure of the Brazil Current at different latitudes, the relationship of the Brazil Current with the location and strength of the gyre, and the effect of the large-scale wind forcing. Complementary satellite altimetry and model reanalysis data will provide a quasi-synoptic view of the mean and eddy flow of the Brazil Current, as well as the impact of Rossby wave mechanisms on the current variability. A process-based study using global eddy-permitting ocean model simulations will be performed for separating the influence of local and remote wind forcing. These runs will be compared against a nested eddy-resolving regional model of the western South Atlantic domain to investigate how the mesoscale eddy processes may respond to and feedback on the regional variability at longer timescales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on studying the interannual variability of the Brazil Current (BC) using models and observations, and its interactions with the gyre and meridional overturning circulations.

This project allowed the first daily reconstruction of the velocity and transport of the BC since 1993 using XBT transect data (22°S and 34°S), Argo and satellite altimetry data, published in two papers (Schmid and Majumder, 2018; Goes et al., 2019). XBTs measure temperature only, and rely on T-S lookup tables to infer salinity to investigate its velocity structure. We created a new method to infer salinity for temperature profiles in the whole Atlantic Ocean, (Goes et al., 2018). This allowed typical velocity errors due to salinity for the BC region of only 6 cm/s.

The mean BC transport was 4.7 Sv, with an additional 0.9 Sv over the shelf. The seasonal variability of the BC transport at 22°S is characterized by a maximum in the summer and a minimum in the winter. This is the opposite of the classical Sverdrup transport, which points to a delayed ocean adjustment via planetary waves. The propagating planetary waves explain the very good match between the BC and the wind stress curl with a 19-month delay. During the summer 2009/2010, a marine heat wave affected the region anomalously raising the temperature by ~3°C. During this event the BC transport increased to more than 11Sv for more than 3 months. The examination of this event showed that the temperature anomalies were overlaid by anticyclonic wind anomalies that increased the coastal upwelling in the region. The mix between increased upwelling, increased temperature offshore and one stationary eddy explained the BC behavior in this event. These results were published in Goes et al. (2019).

To better understand how remotely propagating features can influence interannual variability on the western boundary, a Complex Empirical Orthogonal Function (CEOF) analysis was performed on the satellite-derived sea surface height. The first three CEOF modes show clear westward propagation similar to baroclinic Rossby waves, and these take several years to cross the basin. A strong correlation is found between the first CEOF mode and the sea level pressure and sea surface temperature characteristic of the Niño 3.4, and it dominates South Atlantic variability until 2005. The first mode decays after 2005, which is observed in SSH observations, and can potentially be related to a change to a more central (Modoki) type Niño teleconnection. The variability of the COEF modes are shown to be associated with the BC variability at 34°S and 22°S. These results improve overall understanding of the dynamics of the South Atlantic and can potentially improve the predictability of the Meridional Overturning Circulation (MOC) and extreme coastal sea level in South America. These results were published in Majumder et al., 2019.

To further understand the interaction of the MOC, sea level and the western boundary current, the paper Volkov et al., (2019) used satellite altimetry data and ocean reanalyses to identify how the large scale gyre circulation can affect the coastal sea level and the Gulf Stream. We identify a tripole mode of the ocean gyre-scale sea surface height variability in the North Atlantic and show that this mode is responsible for most of the interannual-to-decadal sea surface height changes along the southeast coast of the United States, including the Gulf of Mexico. We also show that these changes are largely driven by the large-scale heat divergence related to the MOC and linked to the low-frequency North Atlantic Oscillation. This tripole mode explains the warming of the Gulf Stream since 2010.

This project sponsored three post-docs, who led or participated in several papers (Majumder et al., 2019; Goes et al., 2019, Germineau et al., 2019) and scientific meetings. Also, a summer intern from a local public high school was mentored during this project. The student learned the basics of oceanography and programming. A professional master student was also mentored during this project and he based his thesis on the results produced during his internship. The PIs participated in several open houses from NOAA and the University of Miami, including one at the Frost Science Museum and one at FIU University. These open houses focused on showing the general public how ocean observations are used to benefit society. This project strengthened the collaboration between the University of Miami, NOAA/AOML and researchers from three Brazilian Universities with an outcome of three joint publications. One publication has become the master thesis of a Brazilian student from Federal University of Bahia (Lima et al., 2016). Joint meetings and presentations took place during conferences such as the USAMOC meeting (Santa Fe, 2017), the Ocean Sciences meeting (New Orleans, 2018), the OSTST meeting (Miami, 2017), ICSCHMO (Sydney, 2018), and Ocean Predict (Halifax, 2019).
